BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be exceptionally warm. The danger of wet avalanches will already be elevated in the early morning. Some snow will fall in the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the early morning the natural activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. This applies on steep east and west facing slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep south facing slopes in all altitude zones, this also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m. In some cases the wet avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach large size.

On steep grassy slopes individual medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. In steep gullies wet avalanches can in some cases reach areas without any snow cover.

Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started very early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will already be soft in the early morning. Until the evening the weather will be exceptionally warm. The high temperatures will give rise to extreme and thorough wetting of the snowpack especially on very steep slopes. These conditions will cause a rapid weakening of the snowpack.
In some regions 10 to 25 cm of snow will fall in the evening. The wind will be strong to storm force in particular on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north. As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, mostly small wind slabs will form towards the evening. The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow. Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be exceptionally warm. The danger of wet avalanches will already be elevated in the early morning. Some snow will fall in the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the early morning the natural activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. This applies on steep east and west facing slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep south facing slopes in all altitude zones, this also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m. In some cases the wet avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach large size.

On steep grassy slopes individual medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. In steep gullies wet avalanches can in some cases reach areas without any snow cover.

Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started very early and concluded timely.

The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will already be soft in the early morning. Until the evening the weather will be exceptionally warm. The high temperatures will give rise to extreme and thorough wetting of the snowpack especially on very steep slopes. These conditions will cause a rapid weakening of the snowpack.
In some regions 10 to 25 cm of snow will fall in the evening. The wind will be strong to storm force in particular on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north. As a consequence of new snow and a strong wind, mostly small wind slabs will form towards the evening. The fresh wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow. Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be exceptionally warm. The danger of wet avalanches will already be elevated in the early morning. Little snow will fall in the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the early morning the natural activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. This applies on steep east and west facing slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep south facing slopes in all altitude zones, this also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m. In some cases the wet avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach large size.

On steep grassy slopes individual medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided. In steep gullies wet avalanches can in some cases reach areas without any snow cover.

Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started very early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will already be soft in the early morning. Until the evening the weather will be exceptionally warm. The high temperatures will give rise to extreme and thorough wetting of the snowpack especially on very steep slopes. These conditions will cause a rapid weakening of the snowpack.
In particular in the north in some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall in the evening. The wind will be strong to storm force in particular on the Main Alpine Ridge and to the north. The fresh wind slabs are mostly very small.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow. Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be exceptionally warm. The danger of wet avalanches will increase during the day. Some snow will fall in the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In the early morning the natural activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. This applies on steep east and west facing slopes below approximately 2800 m, as well as on steep south facing slopes in all altitude zones, this also applies on shady slopes below approximately 2600 m. In some cases the wet avalanches can release the saturated snowpack and reach large size.

On steep grassy slopes individual medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

Backcountry tours and ascents to alpine cabins should be started very early and concluded timely.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will already be soft in the early morning. Until the evening the weather will be exceptionally warm. The high temperatures will give rise to extreme and thorough wetting of the snowpack especially on very steep slopes. These conditions will cause a rapid weakening of the snowpack.
In particular in the west in some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall in the evening. The fresh wind slabs are mostly very small.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow. Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow above the tree line: As the snowfall level drops the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in high Alpine regions. Dry and moist avalanches can be released in near-surface layers and reach medium size, caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
In particular low altitudes: As a consequence of the rain moist and wet snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. In particular on very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Saturday the weather has been exceptionally warm. These spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m there is still a very large amount of snow.
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night. The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack below the tree line.
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1200 m snow will fall over a wide area. Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow above the tree line: As the snowfall level drops the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in high Alpine regions. Dry and moist avalanches can be released in near-surface layers and reach medium size, caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
In particular low altitudes: As a consequence of the rain moist and wet snow slides are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. In particular on very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Saturday the weather has been exceptionally warm. These spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing settling of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Above approximately 2000 m there is still a very large amount of snow.
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night. The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack below the tree line.
20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1200 m snow will fall over a wide area. Increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow at high altitude: As the snowfall level drops the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in high Alpine regions. Dry and moist avalanches can be released in near-surface layers and reach medium size, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
In particular low altitudes: As a consequence of the rain moist and wet snow slides are possible as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small. In particular on very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been very mild. These spring-like weather conditions gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in some cases in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night. The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack below the tree line. 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 2000 m.
At intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1300 m snow will fall in some regions. In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow at high altitude: As the snowfall level drops the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent in the afternoon.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and southerly wind, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form in high Alpine regions. Dry and moist avalanches can be released in near-surface layers and reach medium size, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
In particular low altitudes: As a consequence of the rain moist and wet snow slides are possible as the day progresses, but they will be mostly small. In particular on very steep grassy slopes these can slide on the ground.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been very mild. These spring-like weather conditions gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in some cases in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night. The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack below the tree line. 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 2000 m.
At intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1300 m snow will fall in some regions. In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Up to high altitudes rain will fall. Moist and wet avalanches and gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the rain wet and gliding avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. In particular on very steep grassy slopes the wet avalanches can slide on the ground.
Slight increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the snowfall level drops. The new snow and wind slabs can be released very easily at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been exceptionally warm. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night.
The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack in all altitude zones. 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 2100 m.
At intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1600 m snow will fall in some regions. In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Up to high altitudes rain will fall. Moist and wet avalanches and gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the rain wet and gliding avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. In particular on very steep grassy slopes the wet avalanches can slide on the ground.
Slight increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the snowfall level drops. The new snow and wind slabs can be released very easily at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.
The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been exceptionally warm. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night.
The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack in all altitude zones. 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 2100 m.
At intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1600 m snow will fall in some regions. In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs will be deposited on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain sometimes large wind slabs will form. Below approximately 2300 m medium-sized to large wet loose snow avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise to rapid moistening of the snowpack over a wide area below approximately 2300 m. As a consequence of new snow and strong wind dry slab avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Up to high altitudes rain will fall. Moist loose snow slides and gliding avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. In particular in extremely steep terrain moist avalanches can slide on the ground.
Individual gliding avalanches can also be released in the night or in the morning. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been exceptionally warm. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night.
The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Up to high altitudes rain will fall. Moist loose snow slides and gliding avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. In particular in extremely steep terrain moist avalanches can slide on the ground.
Individual gliding avalanches can also be released in the night or in the morning. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been exceptionally warm. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night.
The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack in all altitude zones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In these regions above approximately 2500 m in some localities danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above the tree line will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. Especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas they will increase in size as the day progresses.
In particular on very steep slopes and at intermediate and high altitudes medium-sized natural avalanches are possible. Dry avalanches can be released in near-surface layers. Along the border with Switzerland these avalanche prone locations are more widespread.

As a consequence of the precipitation more moist and wet avalanches are possible in the late morning. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and snowfall above approximately 2200 m and the occasionally strong wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the course of the day. 15 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. The weather conditions will cause a rise in the danger of dry avalanches as the day progresses.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack represent the main danger.

Small and medium-sized moist avalanches have been released in the last three days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular on very steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas more small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: In these regions above approximately 2500 m in some localities danger level 3 (considerable) will be reached. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above the tree line will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. Especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas they will increase in size as the day progresses.
In particular on very steep slopes and at intermediate and high altitudes medium-sized natural avalanches are possible. Dry avalanches can be released in near-surface layers. Along the border with Switzerland these avalanche prone locations are more widespread.

As a consequence of the precipitation more moist and wet avalanches are possible in the late morning. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and snowfall above approximately 2200 m and the occasionally strong wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the course of the day. 15 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. The weather conditions will cause a rise in the danger of dry avalanches as the day progresses.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack represent the main danger.

Small and medium-sized moist avalanches have been released in the last three days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular on very steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas more small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding avalanches and moist snow slides are the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of gliding avalanches and wet snow slides being released will increase quickly in all aspects, not only on sunny slopes, including on steep shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. In isolated cases, wet avalanches can reach intermediate altitudes in steep gullies.
Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The surface of the snowpack will freeze very little and will already be soft in the early morning. The high temperatures will give rise to extreme and thorough wetting of the snowpack especially on very steep slopes. These conditions will cause a rapid weakening of the snowpack.
In particular in the west in some localities up to 10 cm of snow will fall in the evening. The fresh wind slabs are mostly very small.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary increase in danger of dry avalanches as a consequence of the new snow. Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Early morning: Up to 2200 m rain will fall. Moist and wet avalanches and wet loose snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the rain wet snow slides and avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones, in particular on very steep slopes at low and intermediate altitudes.
Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the snowfall level drops. The new snow and wind slabs can be released very easily at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.

The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been exceptionally warm. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night.
The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1800 m.
At intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1400 m snow will fall in some regions. In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Early morning: Up to 2200 m rain will fall. Moist and wet avalanches and wet loose snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the rain wet snow slides and avalanches are possible as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones, in particular on very steep slopes at low and intermediate altitudes.
Gradual increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the snowfall level drops. The new snow and wind slabs can be released very easily at high altitude, in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised on very steep slopes.

The current avalanche situation calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Since Friday the weather has been exceptionally warm. The surface of the snowpack cooled hardly at all during the overcast night.
The rain will give rise as the day progresses to rapid moistening of the snowpack at low and intermediate altitudes. 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until the evening above approximately 1800 m.
At intermediate and high altitudes there is still a very large amount of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Above approximately 1400 m snow will fall in some regions. In some localities increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level. Backcountry tours should be started and concluded early. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep slopes above approximately 1900 m, as well as at the base of rock walls. Occasionally large natural avalanches are not ruled out. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at high altitude. These places are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Backcountry tourers or freeriders can release avalanches. In particular on shady slopes the avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night was reduced in some cases. The surface of the snowpack will only just freeze and will soften during the day. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack. This applies on sunny slopes in all altitude zones, as well as on shady slopes also at intermediate and high altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be very warm. Backcountry tours should be started and concluded very early.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of solar radiation the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Gliding avalanches can also occur, in particular on steep grassy slopes.
The wind slabs remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering, especially adjacent to ridgelines. In all regions medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack, especially on shady slopes. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area. The snowpack remains wet all the way through in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above the tree line will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. Especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas they will increase in size as the day progresses.
In particular on very steep slopes and at intermediate and high altitudes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible. Dry avalanches can be released in near-surface layers. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.

As a consequence of the precipitation more moist and wet avalanches are possible in the late morning. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and snowfall above approximately 2200 m and the occasionally strong wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the course of the day. 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. The weather conditions will cause a slight rise in the danger of dry avalanches as the day progresses.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack represent the main danger.

Small and medium-sized moist avalanches have been released in the last three days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular on very steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas more mostly small dry avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche danger will increase during the day.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming in particular above the tree line will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. Especially adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas they will increase in size as the day progresses.
In particular on very steep slopes and at intermediate and high altitudes small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized natural avalanches are possible. Dry avalanches can be released in near-surface layers. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude.

As a consequence of the precipitation more moist and wet avalanches are possible in the late morning. This applies in particular on very steep slopes below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and snowfall above approximately 2200 m and the occasionally strong wind, an unfavourable avalanche situation will develop in the course of the day. 10 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. The weather conditions will cause a slight rise in the danger of dry avalanches as the day progresses.
The near-surface layers of the snowpack represent the main danger.

Small and medium-sized moist avalanches have been released in the last three days.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular on very steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas more mostly small dry avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be exceptionally warm. Wet snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming, the activity of wet avalanches will rapidly increase. This applies in all aspects. In some cases the wet avalanches can release the saturated snowpack. Mostly they are rather small.

On steep grassy slopes mostly small gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Until the evening the weather will be exceptionally warm. The surface of the snowpack will cool hardly at all during the overcast night and will already be soft in the early morning. These conditions will cause a rapid weakening of the snowpack. Hardly any snow is lying at low and intermediate altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Temporary decrease in danger of wet avalanches as the temperature drops. Some snow will fall in some regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The weather will be very warm. As a consequence of warming the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on shady slopes at intermediate and high altitudes. Mostly small avalanches are possible in particular on steep shady slopes. Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack, especially on shady slopes. On sunny slopes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 2000 m: In gullies and bowls mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. The weather will be mild. These weather conditions will give rise to thorough wetting of the old snowpack in all aspects.
